titlestmt.titleproper: Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn research files and interviews, 1991-1996
titlestmt.author: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University

address.addressline: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

did.unittitle: Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn research files and interviews, 1991-1996
did.abstract: Research files of Gary Pomerantz for the publication of his book, Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn: A Saga of Race and Family including audio recordings and transcripts of interviews that he conducted, research material, and manuscript drafts.
did.repository: Emory UniversityManuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library Pitts Theology Library

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies have not been made for all of the audiovisual series at this time. Researchers must contact MARBL in advance for access to these materials.

userestrict.head: Terms Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: All requests subject to limitations noted in departmental policies on reproduction.

prefercite.head: Citation
prefercite.p: [after identification of item(s)], Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn research files and interviews, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Gary M. Pomerantz is an award-winning journalist and author. After graduating from the University of California (Berkeley), Pomerantz joined The Washington Post as a sports reporter. In the 1990s, he moved to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution where he wrote feature stories, and penned columns and editorials. His first book was Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn: A Saga of Race and Family (1996). It tells the story of race relations in 20th century Atlanta through the history of two families: the Allens and the Dobbs. Ivan Allen, Sr., the ambitious son of a Confederate cavalryman, moved to Atlanta from Dalton in 1895. Two years later, John Wesley Dobbs, the ambitious son of a slave, arrived in Atlanta from Cobb County. Over the course of the next two generations both of these families produced future mayors of Atlanta: Ivan Allen, Jr., who was the only southern politician to go to Washington, D.C. to speak in favor of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, and Maynard H. Jackson, the first African American mayor of a southern city. Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn explores the origins and the workings of Atlanta's racial d√©tente. It was named a "Notable Book of the Year" by The New York Times and it was included in The Georgia Center for the Book's "Georgia Top 25 Reading List." His other books include Nine Minutes, Twenty Seconds: A True Story of Tragedy & Triumph (2001) and Wilt, 1962: The Night of 100 Points and the Dawn of a New Era (2005).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials relating to Pomerantz's first book, Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn: A Saga of Race and Family (New York : Scribner, c1996). It includes interviews, interview transcripts, research materials, notebooks and audiovisual materials relating to the history of the Allen and Dobbs families as well as the history of modern Atlanta. Of particular interest are the interviews and interview transcripts, which recount the racial, political, economic and social life of 20th century Atlanta.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: (1) Interview transcripts, (2) Research files, (3) Manuscript drafts, and (4) Audiovisual.

controlaccess.head: Personal Names
controlaccess.persname: Pomerantz, Gary M. Where Peachtree meets Sweet Auburn : the saga of two families and the making of Atlanta.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains typed transcripts of some interviews Pomerantz conducted for the book. Where noted, the original audio cassettes are available in Subseries 3.1: Audio cassettes. It includes a diverse cross-section of Atlantans, including Allen and Dobbs family members, movers and shakers in the black and white business communities (T.M. Alexander, Sr. and Jr., W.L. Calloway, Larry Gellerstedt, Jr. and III, and Joel Goldberg), activists involved in the civil rights movement (Herschelle Sullivan Challenor and Donald Hollowell), journalists on both sides of the color line who covered this era (Paul E.X. Brown, W.L. Fowlkes, Aubrey Morris and Eugene Patterson), and influential political figures in Atlanta and Georgia (Michael Lomax, Herman Talmadge, Ernest Vandiver, and Andrew Young).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The files include transcripts of shorter interviews, such as phone interviews, that were not taped, correspondence, newspaper and magazine clippings, archival research and biographical information. The family files contain genealogical information gathered from the U.S. census, legal records, obituaries and other sources. The five "Reporter's Notebooks" contain notes on a variety of individuals and subjects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (2.1) Research files - Individuals, (2.2) Research files - Subject and (2.3) Reporter's notebooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series includes drafts of individual chapters as well as notes and timelines Pomerantz used to compose the chapters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The audiovisual series contains audio cassettes and two videotapes. The audiotapes consist primarily of interviews conducted by Pomerantz. Transcripts for many of these interviews can be found in Series 1: Interview Transcripts. The videotapes feature Ivan Allen, Jr. and Maynard H. Jackson, Jr. addressing the students in Pomerantz's Journalism class.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies have not been made for all of the audiovisual series at this time. Researchers must contact MARBL in advance for access to these materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: (4.1) Audio cassettes and (4.2) Videotapes.
